qas.question: When did Burke sign a contract for a history of England?
How many words long was Burke's history of England contracted to be?
How many pages long was Burke's history of England contracted to be?
When was Burke's history of England published?
Which author's history of England being published before Burke's might have dissuaded Burke from continuing his?

plausible_answers.text: An Essay Towards an Abridgement of the English History

qas.question: What is the name of David Hume's history?
What critic praised the Frenchness of Burke's text?
When was Hume's history of England published?
How long was the book Robert Dodsley wrote?
How many words was Lord Acton's commentary?

context: On <a0_0>25 February 1757<a0_0/>, Burke signed a contract with Robert Dodsley to write a "history of England from the time of Julius Caesar to the end of the reign of Queen Anne", its length being <b8_0>eighty quarto sheets (<a2_0>640 pages<a2_0/>)<b8_0/>, <a1_0>nearly <b9_0>400,000<b9_0/><a1_0/> words. It was to be submitted for publication by Christmas 1758. Burke completed the work to the year 1216 and stopped; it was not published until after Burke's death, being included in an <a3_0><b7_0>1812<b7_0/><a3_0/> collection of his works, entitled <b5_0>An Essay Towards an Abridgement of the English History<b5_0/>. <b6_0>G. M. Young<b6_0/> did not value Burke's history and claimed that it was "demonstrably a translation from the French". Lord Acton, on commenting on the story that Burke stopped his history because <a4_0>David Hume<a4_0/> published his, said "it is ever to be regretted that the reverse did not occur".
